title: So are stats only useful when they support your narrative?
body:
Right? Because I see shit like "champions with mobility give up nothing and are just more mobile".

Really?  

Then why does it seem like...

https://i.imgur.com/IzlkATd.png

the top win rate charts are full of immobile champions. If mobile champions can _literally do everything_ and immobile one can - then why are immobile champs even remotely good. Wtf.

Wait.. wtf... where are all these mobile champions...

https://i.imgur.com/VMoX9d9.png

that I keep hearing about... Why aren't they dominating the win rates... 

Oh, or maybe mobility/single target damage isn't the only thing important in this game. Maybe immobile champions have power elsewhere in their kits - and having a more forgiving kit doesn't mean shit when you can't have any impact. Yeah sure, you can position worse, but good job - you can be Zed and never die using your mobility while you lose the game cause you don't do anything.

Now imagine if mobile champions actually dominated win rates - you’d constantly see people citing stats. But since stats don’t support it - they are nowhere to be seen.

- "Mobility champions are higher skillcap."

Umm, why? I thought they were literally as good as immobile champions just with more mobility. How can they have a higher skill cap? Ohhh... thats right. When you lose to a Lee Sin, he's low skillcap/braindead easy/too forgiving - but when it comes to his win rate is low, its cause hes too high skillcap. Ok.

HoB Jhin is hardly the norm for speedups. That's like saying Kalista is the norm for a champion with dashes, or Cho'gath is the norm for tanks. It's just not the truth.

{{champion:36}} {{champion:119}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:86}} all have speedups, yet they're *not* mobile champions. Hell, simply *having* a dash doesn't even make you mobile, as demonstrated by {{champion:6}} and {{champion:3}}.

Mobile champions are those that consistently move at high speeds *in combat* and have a noteworthy dash that moves them significantly more than it delays them. Usually, it must also be able to be used for engage or disengage, and must able to be used reactively rather than proactively. Garen does not move fast enough to be considered mobile, neither does Mundo, Draven, or Fiddle. Urgot and Galio have a dash, but it's on a heavy delay and isn't really able to be used reactively.

Yi is mobile because he has a strong speedup and a dash of a kind, both of which are instant. Sivir is mobile because of her passive *and* ult, both of which are reactive. Kled is mobile because of his E, not because of his R (lmfao his R is *only* engage. It can't even be used like Sion's to dash out of combat). Hec is mobile because he has a dash and runs close to the speed of light. The top 5? Only Ahri is mobile.

Depends on the argument. If we're talking about immobile champions being worse than mobile champions then yes. Speed ups are mobility. Just because it's not a straight up dash or blink doesn't mean it isn't mobility.

As long as we're talking mobile vs immobile we count champions with no mobility spell (like a speed up, dash or blink) against champions with mobility (aka champions that have a speed up, dash or blink).

Now here's the deal. If we're talking about the NORM then yes, speed ups could be considered weak enough compared to a dash or blink to be put into the immobile section. We're not talking about the norm though. We're talking mobile vs immobile and that means champions with no mobility spell at all vs the rest.

Edited for clarification: Another thing we have to concider is what kind of dash/blink does a champion have? If it's only on an ult I'd concider that champion immobile because that one mobility spell is gated by a long ass cooldown most of the time. I'd count it as grey area at best.

I think this actually IS the key point.  Let's be brutally blunt for a moment.  The VAST majority of league players are "low elo", as such, I'd say at LEAST 80% of players are not using ANY champ to its maximum potential.  But let's say in 100 games, 20 of them have a Yasuo and 5 of them have a Lux.  If we assume that 20% of players playing a champ (made up percentage, but not important to the point) will play at a high skill level, then I'm going to see 4 badass Yasuos vs. 1 Lux.  Ie. I get killed more often by high mobility champions if taken purely as a flat "number of games/plays", even though statistically it may be essentially the same BY PERCENTAGE.

Also, as others have already noted, popularity definitely skews the skill situation.  Aurelion Soll is LITERALLY only played by ONE person in the entire NA LCS (in actual pro matches) but is banned against that guy (and ONLY that guy, literally NO ONE else) because he's the ONLY guy that does it.  When a champion is "weak", the only people that really play them competitively truly love the champion and thus will (more often than not) have a MUCH higher level of familiarity with the champ.  In extreme cases, I can totally believe there are players that are "gold" on their one trick that would be bronze on ANY other champion (regardless of lane).
